captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

So there's a great essay
written by Sigmund Freud called
"On Transience."

And in it, he cites
a conversation

that he had with
the poet, Rilke,

as they were walking along
this beautiful garden.

And at one point, Rilke looked
like he was about to tear up.
And Freud said, what's wrong?
It's a beautiful day.

There's beautiful
plants around us.
This is magnificent.

And then Rilke says, well,
I can't get over the fact

that one day all of
this is going to die.

All these trees,
all these plants,
all this life is going to decay.

Everything dissolves
in meaninglessness

when you think about the
fact that impermanence
is a really real thing.

Perhaps the greatest existential
bummer of all is entropy.

And I was really struck by
this, because perhaps that's

why, when we're in love,
we're also kind of sad.

There's a sadness
to the ecstasy.

Beautiful things sometimes
can make us a little sad.

And it's because
what they hint at

is the exception, a
vision of something

more, a vision of a
hidden door, a rabbit

hole to fall through,
but a temporary one.

And I think, ultimately,
that is the tragedy.

That is why love simultaneously
fills us with melancholy.

That's why sometimes I feel
nostalgic over something

I haven't lost yet, because
I see its transience.

And so how does one
respond to this?
Do we love harder?
Do we squeeze tighter?

Or do we embrace the Buddhist
creed of no attachment?

Do we pretend not to care that
everything and everyone we know

is going to be
taken away from us?

And I don't know if
I can accept that.

I think I more side with the
Dylan Thomas quote that says,

I will not go quietly
into that good night,

but instead rage against
the dying of the light.

I think that we defy
entropy and impermanence
with our films and our poems.

I think we hold onto each
other a little harder and say,
I will not let go.

I do not accept the ephemeral
nature of this moment.
I'm going to extend it forever.
Or at least I'm going to try.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
[MUSIC PLAYING]

comments.text:
Several misconceptions:

1. Freud's legitimacy; pretty much everything of his has been disproven 
scientifically
2. Buddhism advocating 'not caring'; this is your own misconception
3. Trying harder, or making art will extend life; it most definitely will 
fade to dust, like everyone and anything you know
4. 7 billion people should make films and art or else their lives will have 
no meaning﻿

comments.text:
He maybe doesn't so much understand Buddhism. If he is going to try to 
extend moments forever he may as well try nailing jello to a wall. To me, 
the cool thing is that while most of the stuff in our lives is ephemeral, 
there is always something else coming. I've prevented or postponed 
something even better from occurring by trying to grasp onto the thing that 
was slipping away. Acceptance of change does not necessarily mean that one 
"pretends not to care." I see no bummer in impermanence. After all, if 
things were not impermanent it would be a very bizarre and joyless world.﻿

comments.author: khiar ilyas

comments.text:
The buddhists don't pretend they don't care. They train themselves to be 
truly present in the now, and thus their minds won't wonder off or convert 
their fear of transience into disturbing thoughts that ruin amazing 
moments. Maybe that is the only way to experience the timelessness of love.
As for art, in my opinion, we shouldn't do it to defy our impermanence (as 
he proposes), I think that's very egotistical. Making art needs no purpose. 
Art for a purpose perhaps is not even art. Expressing yourself comes 
naturally and even though it might lead to something timeless, that 
shouldn't be the goal but just the consequence. 
Entropy is an existential bummer only if one's existance is understood in 
terms of his ego. Because if you see yourself as part of a bigger process 
of constant change, it shouldn't really matter.
Just to be clear, I haven't mastered ANY of the above and completely 
sympathise with what the guy is saying! I 'm just not sure about his method 
of dealing with it.﻿

comments.text:
Do Not Go Gentle Into That Good Night - Dylan Thomas

Do not go gentle into that good night,
Old age should burn and rave at close of day;
Rage, rage against the dying of the light.

Though wise men at their end know dark is right,
Because their words had forked no lightning they
Do not go gentle into that good night.

Good men, the last wave by, crying how bright
Their frail deeds might have danced in a green bay,
Rage, rage against the dying of the light.

Wild men who caught and sang the sun in flight,
And learn, too late, they grieve it on its way,
Do not go gentle into that good night.

Grave men, near death, who see with blinding sight
Blind eyes could blaze like meteors and be gay,
Rage, rage against the dying of the light.

And you, my father, there on the sad height,
Curse, bless, me now with your fierce tears, I pray.
Do not go gentle into that good night.
Rage, rage against the dying of the light.﻿

comments.text:
I used to fear death the same as everyone else, I suppose a small part of 
me still does. But lately i've been thinking about death and what comes 
after death and i've realized that there is no after death. all we are is 
the accumulation of our thoughts and experiences. When you lose those, you 
lose all forms of being. I think most people are frightened by this, but 
i'm not, I look forward to this. the only reason people fear death is 
because they're concious of it. without conciousness, there is no fear, no 
nothing. what comes after death is peaceful nothingness.﻿

comments.text:
This emotions and intuitions are not only human, they are right. Which is 
amazing. Now that does not respond to why we are here, just the mechanism 
that brings us here :)

In his influential 1944 monograph “What Is Life?” the eminent quantum 
physicist Erwin Schrödinger argued that this is what living things must do. 
A plant, for example, absorbs extremely energetic sunlight, uses it to 
build sugars, and ejects infrared light, a much less concentrated form of 
energy. The overall entropy of the universe increases during photosynthesis 
as the sunlight dissipates, even as the plant prevents itself from decaying 
by maintaining an orderly internal structure.

https://www.quantamagazine.org/20140122-a-new-physics-theory-of-life﻿

comments.text:
What you can extend forever is the feeling within you that you feel when 
you feel love, for you are made of the stuff.  Love is what you are.  You 
would not be able to feel that delicious, glorious feeling if it wasn't in 
you.  Problem is, we tend to connect it to the externals that trigger it in 
us and those things are fleeting, indeed, but the feeling is forever.  You 
can feel it at any time, wherever you are, no matter who is there or not 
there, as you wish.  Make it your goal to learn how to feel it at will.  ﻿

comments.text:
Existentialism is entropy!  It's the vicious circle of believing that who 
we are is our body and not infinite beings. Unfortunately, the view of the 
Buddhist approach of non-attachment is seen in the context of having to 
"fight" attachment to discard it ... good luck with that!  The irony of 
life is if we are able to accept compassionately that we have attachment(s) 
they no longer have the same effect on us, they drift into the background, 
become a fly on the wall.  ﻿
comments.author: Kathy Bibby

comments.text:
"Every event that has taken place in this universe has led you to this 
moment. Every star exploding, every planet colliding, every molecule 
combining, every quantum occurrence, every life that arises, every 
adaption, every evolution of every species, every birth, every death, every 
thought, every realization, and every action taken by anyone who has ever 
lived. The real question is: What will you do with this moment?" - 
Anonymous﻿

comments.text:
We have similar thoughts on that dilemma, but one thing is different in my 
perspective. I am almost sure that life after death is possible, not in our 
physical , material form, but in something else, call it whatever you want, 
spiritual, energetic or something third. People are preoccupied on material 
plane, that everything has to decay and die. That fact we have to take for 
granted because it is absolute truth, BUT our exsistance doesn't end there. 
If you look at present life it is a collection of memories, previous and 
next lives also, where in afterlife(time between lives) we examine our 
memories of past lives and learn from them. In my humble opinion, we have 
to stop worry about death and decay, and focus to enjoy in our present 
life, and learn our memories and  previous lives. just my 2 cents﻿

The realm we exist only satisfies the limits of sensory perceptions; the 
debut of the event eventually subsides like a flash of a feature of 
elemental emotion. It would be non-transient events such as a 
life-like-dream if lucid or other; that would propel the senses to exceed 
the mundane. To emerge into spiritual ramifications this would be what a 
transcendent moment that prophet(s) would describe as, "transcending the 
boundaries of this world with the soul or spirt."  #blackplight4u  ﻿
comments.author: blackplight4u

comments.text:
I have often thought this in moments of pure joy doing whatever I'm doing 
or experiencing hardship in whatever form or circumstance. And this thought 
comes to me that at some point this moment will become meaningless to me 
and or the world. So what can I do to set this moment apart from the rest 
and change it from meaningless to meaningful regardless of the inevitable 
outcome of 'dust to dust'. I think that will supplement the acceptance of 
the inevitable, the yang to the ying or the ying to the yang! 

Great video! Will be checking out the others :)﻿
comments.author: PPPPaula

comments.text:
Because the human brain is practically hard wired to live everywhere but 
the present moment.  Your brain can't even comprehend what the present is 
because it's gone.  People chase all sorts of phantoms believing they are 
the key to the perfect life they want or happiness or riches.  Then when 
they catch up to one, they grasp at it with both hands and squeeze tight 
only to open their eyes and see they were holding on to nothing all along.

comments.author: ook park

comments.text:
He doesn't understand the "no attachment" thing.
I wrestled with it for a long time as well but finally understood it 
through the golden rule of all religion "What you do not wish for yourself, 
do not do to others.".
We are all the same, all one. When you die there are still so many people 
like you left; the little differences that make you you do not matter at 
all in the grand scheme of things. Do not cling to your ego so desperately. 
Everything must pass, but all is a cycle, that is the way of things. Summer 
becomes winter, but in the spring all will bloom again.
The "no attachment" bit is so that you do not value yourself above all 
others, because that will make you shit all over the golden rule.﻿
comments.author: Zoolbar's Magic Star Cave

comments.text:
Fuck extremes, i tried felt inner peace then watched to this guy, he may 
not be buddist but is capable of making you feel joy and passion trough his 
own passion, like an awesome virus. Now I'm starting to use emotions again, 
using them to evoke good feelings on people i come in contact with. Dalai 
Lama can't make you feel that way, It's the best feeling in the world to be 
able to inspire people and have a good time on Earth. I think happiness is 
in the balance, not in the extremes. I am not attached to things out of  my 
control, always looking for the good sides of everything but at the same 
time i feel joy and passion for live. Remember this quote by Nietzsche 
"Convictions are more dangerous enemies of truth than lies." Stop hating 
and learn from everyone.
comments.author: Sebastián Jácome
